citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The kookaburra has an overgrown beak. The lower beak extends well beyond the length of the upper beak and also
appears misshapen. An overgrown beak may impair a bird's ability to eat and groom normally. The bird must be examined
by a veterinarian to address this issue.

Only one attendant was present for a public tour with approximately 20 guests that were allowed to interact with the
animals. The visitors walked through the animal enclosures with kangaroos, wallabies, and alpacas and were encouraged
to feed and pet several of these animals.
A responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods
of public contact. The facility must provide an adequate number of attendants to ensure any interactions with the animals
are conducted in a safe manner for both the animals and the public.
Correct by: June 9, 2024

A wooden fence post in the southwestern side of the kangaroo enclosure is leaning and pulling on the wire fencing. In
addition, the metal fencing in the emu enclosure near the water receptacle has pieces of broken wire that are pointing
inward into the enclosure.
Unstable, bent or broken fencing may cause entrapment or other injuries to the animals. Maintenance issues must be
identified and addressed in a timely manner to keep the facility structurally sound and in good repair, safeguard the
animals from injury and to contain the animals.

The main food storage room has large metal cans of pelleted feed, and one of the lids is dented and no longer appears to
fit the can. In addition, the room has empty feed bags, debris and clutter noted around the cans.
Food must be stored properly to prevent contamination, deterioration and spoilage. All open supplies of food must be
stored in leak-proof containers with a lid. The food storage room also requires cleaning and organization.

A section of the perimeter fence near the southeastern portion of the facility is well below the 6-foot requirement. The wire
fencing appears to be bent in the center, thus lowering its height.
Outdoor housing facilities must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and
unauthorized persons out. A perimeter fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by
restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the
facility. A system must be in place to maintain a perimeter fence that is at least 6 feet in height.

The cardboard box and wooden perches in the kookaburra enclosure are covered with a thick coating of dried fecal
material. The bird cannot use these structures without coming in contact with the excreta. In addition, the metal surfaces
of the bird's enclosure have dried debris present and should be cleaned.
The bird's enclosure must be cleaned and sanitized as often as necessary to prevent the accumulation of dirt, debris, food
waste, excreta, and other disease hazards. The licensee must ensure that all surfaces in contact with the bird may be
readily cleaned and/or sanitized or be replaced when worn or soiled.
Correct by: May 17, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The kookaburra has an overgrown beak. The lower beak extends well beyond the length of the upper beak and also 
appears misshapen. An overgrown beak may impair a bird's ability to eat and groom normally. The bird must be examined 
by a veterinarian to address this issue. 
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
Only one attendant was present for a public tour with approximately 20 guests that were allowed to interact with the 
animals. The visitors walked through the animal enclosures with kangaroos, wallabies, and alpacas and were encouraged 
to feed and pet several of these animals.  
 
A responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods 
of public contact. The facility must provide an adequate number of attendants to ensure any interactions with the animals 
are conducted in a safe manner for both the animals and the public. 
 
Correct by: June 9, 2024 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
A wooden fence post in the southwestern side of the kangaroo enclosure is leaning and pulling on the wire fencing. In 
addition, the metal fencing in the emu enclosure near the water receptacle has pieces of broken wire that are pointing 
inward into the enclosure. 
 
Unstable, bent or broken fencing may cause entrapment or other injuries to the animals. Maintenance issues must be 
identified and addressed in a timely manner to keep the facility structurally sound and in good repair, safeguard the 
animals from injury and to contain the animals. 
3.125(c)  Repeat

Facilities, general. 
The main food storage room has large metal cans of pelleted feed, and one of the lids is dented and no longer appears to 
fit the can. In addition, the room has empty feed bags, debris and clutter noted around the cans. 
 
Food must be stored properly to prevent contamination, deterioration and spoilage. All open supplies of food must be 
stored in leak-proof containers with a lid. The food storage room also requires cleaning and organization. 
3.127(d)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
A section of the perimeter fence near the southeastern portion of the facility is well below the 6-foot requirement. The wire 
fencing appears to be bent in the center, thus lowering its height. 
 
Outdoor housing facilities must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and 
unauthorized persons out. A perimeter fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by 
restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the 
facility. A system must be in place to maintain a perimeter fence that is at least 6 feet in height. 
3.153(a)(1)(ix) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The cardboard box and wooden perches in the kookaburra enclosure are covered with a thick coating of dried fecal 
material. The bird cannot use these structures without coming in contact with the excreta. In addition, the metal surfaces 
of the bird's enclosure have dried debris present and should be cleaned. 
 
The bird's enclosure must be cleaned and sanitized as often as necessary to prevent the accumulation of dirt, debris, food 
waste, excreta, and other disease hazards. The licensee must ensure that all surfaces in contact with the bird may be 
readily cleaned and/or sanitized or be replaced when worn or soiled.  
 
Correct by: May 17, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
